title: Which team will win the 2020 NBA Finals?
possible_answers: There will be no 2020 NBA Finals winner
preds: Lakers still have it.  Heat used up all their luck.  LJ and Davis will come out swinging.

Series is now 3-2 for the LAL. Sunday's game is currently LAL -5, which equates to roughly a 66% chance of winning. Assuming a line of -7 for Game 7 (if required) puts LAL at about 91% of winning one game in the next two.
That was a big win for Miami. There is still hope.
Updating as time passes, lakers 3-1 lead

At the beginning I predicted Lakers in 5. Lebron has never lost a 3-1 advantage in the playoffs on any team, him and Davis haven't played well the last two games and are overdue for a stellar performance, and it took a near superhuman performance by Butler to pull out even one win against the Lakers. Maybe the Heat force a Game 6, but I can't see them winning three in a row given their opposition and injuries.

I'm willing to commit considering the Heat would have to... well, heat up, and win the next three games in a row to take the Finals. If they do, then they absolutely deserve it, and I'll live with it. But the "do it for Mamba" narrative is powerful and I've seen LeBron singlehandedly win a series. Kobe put up 60 points his last game... not improbable for LeBron to do the same in tribute.

- LAL are up 3-1
- Teams up 3-1 in the finals are 34/35 (base 97%)
- The one team to recover from 3-1 had Lebron on it.

The competition, which has been a duel between LeBron James and Jimmy Butler in fact in game 4, is now lopsided heavily towards Los Angeles Lakers, and psychology for the Lakers suggests their victory in game 5, which is the NBA title, on 09 October 2020.
/Lakers have 2 wins ahead comfortably, Heat needs 3 wins: totally different starting point.
/Lakers overcame their micro-crisis in game 3, which shows their reliability as a team and resilience to stress.
/Lakers are "almost there", which sometimes sets free superpowers, and they will not want to let it go.
/If Lakers win, they win 3 out of 4 quarters of each game brilliantly, up to 14 points lead per quarter (game 1 3rd quarter, MIA 20 - 34 LAL) and lose one quarter. If the Heat win a game against the Lakers, they have to fight to win each of the four quarters, as in game 3, and they win their quarters by a very low margin (1st: 3pts, 2nd: 1pt, 3rd:1 pt, 4th: 6 pts). One moment of weakness or a few disoriented minutes, one messed-up quarter: the Heat can win three quarters of the game and still lose the match and the championship, on any of the next three possible occasions. The pressure is immense, and perhaps the Heat team collapses under it already in game 5.
Average of 538 numbers still only has the lakes at 69%

- In 425 NBA playoff series teams with a 2-0 lead won 93.6% of the time
- in 34 NBA finals  teams with a 2-0 lead won 88.2%
- Lebron is 23-0 in playoff series with a 2-0 lead
- Starting PG is listed as doubtful for game 3 (however, Nunn was the starting PG for most of the year)
- Starting PG has a  plantar fascia tear.  Normal recovery is 12 weeks. 
- Starting C is listed as doubtful for game 3, but has told reporters he plans to play, likelihood 25-50%
-
Can Miami turn around 0:2 with key players missing? Most probably not...

No Bam, no Dragic, AD on fire, Rondo shooting better than ever before, and James being James. The Lakers are 2 and 0 and show no signs of slowing down for this series. The real question now isn't so much whether they will win but how many games it will take.
First game 98:116. Several injured. Does not look good for Miami...

@Jtrusz points out that the team that wins the first game wins the whole thing 4/5 times. This coupled with the Lakers'' general dominance and Heat very much going into this as underdogs, it's hard to see Heat winning it.

- LAA win game 1. 
- 4 of last 5 NBA finals game 1 winners won the championship. 
- Heat's starting PG Dragic injures foot, return unlikely.

Going in a a little sharper than the crowd (totally agree to the trend), as many haven´t adjusted after the last game yet. In Basketball the better team usually wins, in contrast to soccer for example, where one minute lack of attention, a little luck or the referee can change it all. According to all data I found, the Lakers are the better team.

Does not reflect current view of probability, but overcorrects for my anti-Lakers bias throughout the early portions of forecast period. But not too far off from current view.  Miami doesn’t look like they’re in the same league.

Game 1 of the Finals was over by halftime. Heat couldn't even hit 100 points and the Lakers rested their stars for the entire fourth quarter, it was men against boys at both ends of the floor. It may not be a sweep, but with Bam potentially injured/hurt and the dominance of Davis and James throughout the game I don't see a realistic way for the Heat to win 4 in 6.

Never say never with sports. Lakers are the clear favourites, but Heat definitely have a chance (and the element of surprise). Tomorrow's game will set the tone.  https://www.espn.co.uk/nba/story/_/id/29986051/nba-finals-storylines-stats-matter-ahead-lakers-heat

The current betting exchange price has the Lakers in at roughly 77% chance to win. I think the market is probably unsure as to how the Heat have advanced this far and is a little fearful of yet another upset. I have the Lakers ever so slightly more likely to win. An injury to either side to a key player would be extremely significant.
Continuing to blindly follow an amalgamation of 538's ELO and RAPTOR scores.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nba-predictions/

- Finals are set, Miami (5) vs Lakers (1)
- Lakers have an additional rest day
- Lakers beat Miami 2-0 during the season (prior to COVID break)
- Playoff Offensive rating : Heat 113 Lakers 116
- Playoff Defense rating : Heat 109  Lakers 108
- Highest ranking team won 7 of last 10 championships
- Miami is a 5 seed. The last 5 or below to win was 1995

The LA Lakers are done with the Nuggets, winning 4 - 1 in an obviously strong series performance.
If I weren't at 100% on the Lakers already, I would certainly go for it now. The schedule for the best-of-seven finals games series is already published, the decisive game 7 is scheduled for 13 October 2020, so well ahead of the closing date of this question. If nothing drastic happens to the teams, or to the society (which would question the value of sports for the time being), there will be a 2020 champion on 13 October, or, if they have to push one of the games by one or two days (very unlikely), on 15 October 2020 at the very latest.
Continuing to track with 538. Despite listening the "Whistle Blower" podcast at the moment, I refuse to believe this could be fixed.

Lakers best Heat in 61.1% of stats listed here: https://www.espn.com/nba/stats/team/_/view/team/table/offensive/sort/avgPoints/dir/desc Post-season, Lakers and Heat are in a dead heat in terms of topping stats: https://stats.nba.com/teams/traditional/?SeasonType=Playoffs&sort=PLUS_MINUS&dir=-1 Does that mean anything? Likely not.
Needless to say, the Heat are hot right now. What a story... LaBron against the Heat, a year after Kobe. Are we in a Disney movie? ESPN *is* owned by Disney, after all. Or the Celtics could come back big time. Or not.

Nuggets and Celtics are both down and lost their last game. A team with Lebron James has never lost a 3-1 lead in the playoffs, so that's virtually a done deal. The Celtics still have a shot, but given their inability to seal games against the Heat they are unlikely to win the title even if they do get through.
The Nuggets are not out yet nor are the Celtics

- 21 Sep 4 teams remain (Lakers up 2-0 over Den, Miami up 2-1 over Celtics)
- COVID protocols have been outstanding with no positive tests since the bubble began 
- Highest ranking team won 7 of last 10 championships
- Miami is a 5 seed. The last 5 or below to win was 1995
- Lebron James has been in the finals 9 or the last 10 years.

Lakers are by far the most experienced team, and the team with the best player nearly always wins. More specifically, Denver will not beat LA, as this is a nightmare matchup for them. Boston has no experience and will not beat LA in the finals, even if they beat Miami. Miami probably has the best chance after LA but their team simply doesn't have the firepower that LA does. LA has the best closer, the best two players remaining, and is the heavy heavy favorite.

In the 2020 NBA playoffs, the ranking of the remaining teams are ->
5 = Miami, 3 = Boston, 1 = LA Lakers, 3 = Denver
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_NBA_playoffs#Bracket Looking at the 20 previous NBA playoffs from 2000 - 2019, I found that teams who won were ranked ->
1 = 50% = 10/20, 2 = 30% = 6/20, 3 = 20% = 4/20 Given only teams ranked 1-3 have won in the last 20 years, I will assume that Miami with its 5 ranking have a minimal chance of winning the 2020 NBA Championship ->
Miami = 5% The most recent NBA winner not ranked from 1-3 I found was in 1995 -> 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1995_NBA_playoffs#Bracket Giving the other teams their probability ->
Boston = 21% = (20% / (20% + 50% + 20%)) * 0.95
LA Lakers = 53% = (50% / (20% + 50% + 20%)) * 0.95
Denver = 21% = (20% / (20% + 50% + 20%)) * 0.95 I decided to reduce Boston from 21% to 10% given they are 0-2 games against Miami ->
LA Lakers = 61% = 53% / (21% + 53%) * (100% - 10% - 5%)
Denver = 24% = 21% / (21% + 53%) * (100% - 10% - 5%)

Adjusted upwards for Hayward return. However, only 6% of teams have come back from down 2-0. So base rate for celtics should be around 3% but moved upwards for now. Will readjust following west game 1 and East game 3
Any of the 4 teams could win and it is still possible another police killing results in a cancellation of the season.

Lakers - Nuggets = 70% / 30%
Celtics - Miami = 60% / 40% Lakers - Celtics = 70% / 30%
Lakers - Miami = 70% / 30%
Celtics - Nuggets = 60% / 40%
Miami - Nuggets = 50% / 50% The above gives a tree where:
Lakers get 49%
Celtics 23.4%
Miami 14.4%
Nuggets 13.2% I am adjusting the math, adding my intuition:
Lakers 55% (Kobe year)
Celtics 30% (Celtics are better than 23.4%)
Miami 8% (Sorry, you have to beat the Celtics AND the Lakers, close to impossible)
Nuggets 7% (see same as Miami above) So in my view it is very likely that we see a classic Lakers-Celtics finals series AND Lebron wins it with a 3rd team AND Kobe smiles from heaven :) Go Lakers Nation! (Yes this is probably the most biased question I have answered but I really think I am objective here) After all I’m not too far from the Elo based prediction in 538:
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nba-predictions/

Nuggets 13 points ahead in the 4thQ 8 minutes to go. The LA Clippers won't make it to the conference finals in 2020, it seems.
Added Miami also to my forecast again with respect to their 1  -  0  lead against Boston Celtics in the EC finals as of today. At least three more games left for Boston to show they're the better team and they deserve the finals classic Boston Celtics vs. Los Angeles Lakers...

The Lakers are waiting to play either the Clippers or the Nuggets. The Clippers struggled in the first series and may end up losing a 3-1 lead against the Nuggets. The Nuggets, on the other hand, have gone 3-1 down in both series before coming back and winning the first and (currently) tying the second. A team with Lebron James has never given up a 3-1 series lead and the Lakers were clinical both defensively and offensively in their 4-game streak to eliminate the Rockets. I think they coast comfortably to the finals (probably in 5 games, maybe 6) where they are well positioned to give either the Celtics or the Heat a good contest. On the other side, the Celtics are favorites in my book, especially after the Heat showed an inability to comfortably deal with a crippled Bucks team. The Heat have only lost 1 game in the playoffs so far, however, so its entirely possible they win the series and go to the Championship.

So much for the Houston Rockets... Also, the Bubble seems to be holding up and no reported covid-19 outbreaks almost two weeks after guests entered.  The NBA might make it through the playoffs after all.
With only 5 teams left there are only so many options.

Los Angeles y los Lakers son los equipos que se encuentran mejor preparados para ganar los play-offs de la nba para este 2020, esto se debe a que poseen jugadores de mayor categoría que los demás equipos y sus jugadores juegan de mejor manera.

We're now getting to the portion of the playoffs were you can start thinking about team matchups. At this point Another team == Miami Heat, who actually have a legitimate chance of winning it all.  Right now, I really like the Celtics and the Clippers. Both have a lot of talented wing players and that seems to be the key to playoff success recently. They have talented shooters and under-performed in the regular season due to injuries but now are mostly healthy (excluding Gordon Hayward who should be back for the ECF and the finals). The Celtics will likely have a relatively easy path to the finals with the Raptors and most likely the Heat. The Clippers have a probably the easiest path in the west (Denver is definitely the weakest team out there) and have the star power to win. I'm not super confident in the Lakers given how tough Houston is and how little shooting they have on their roster. LeBron is amazing, but I don't see the 3-point threats he had with the Cavs. Bucks look like they are going to lose to the Heat and even if they pull of the miracle and come back, they'll have to win two tough series.
Based of agregate nba finals forecasts

There's a 5% chance that there won't be a finals winner due to the current pandemic, something can cause it to not happen. And due the the current Black Lives Matter movement, players can decide to not play future matches.
The lakers have a high chance of winning shown by their strong position throughout the season. With LeBron and Anthony Davis in great form, I think they are set to win.

No team has ever come back from a 3-0 deficit in the NBA playoffs. On a good week, the Bucks have the fire power and defensive prowess to win 4 in a row against the Heat, but their most recent contest was not a pretty sight. Giannis looked to pick up an ankle injury in the 1st quarter and the entire offense was outscored by Jimmy Butler alone in the 4th, where they gave up a sizeable lead to lose by 15. I'm downgrading them from 33% to 2% because of historical precedent on top of their most recent performance.
The Heat are undefeated in the playoffs thus far, which gets them 10 of the 31 points I just deducted from the Bucks. However, history suggests that the most likely champ remains a number one seed, which leaves the Lakers to absorb the remaining 21 points.

Continuing to loosely track 538,  Boston significant favorites, and Lakers not rated very highly. Boston are likely to hit the finals the freshest, with the Clippers and Lakers fighting it out in their conference final.  https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nba-predictions/

Just went through a mental model of likely outcomes. Considering who is hot and who is not... considering momentum, considering who is tired and battle 3-3 series splits. Who is punching above their weight and who has had the horse shot out from under them. I’ll likely come to my senses in the morning but this isn’t much of a departure from regularly scheduled programming. I’m not sure how much of the crowd are longtime basketball fans and how many folks are going based on stats. 
Looking at 538 and Ringer projections, I’m just as confused. Some of their updates make no sense. Either way, I enjoy questions like this where I can tweak in a quasi-daily, quasi-informed fashion.

Reviewed the guest bubble protocol and it does look tight.  However, covid has shown a remarkable ability to pop up in places that seem to have it covered (see South Korea, France).  Check back in mid-September to see if any cases have appeared in the bubble. Otherwise, following fivethirtyeight (roughly)
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nba-predictions/?ex_cid=rrpromo

Bucks have most talent and depth, which makes them consistently dangeorus. Raptors are top 2 in offense and top 4 in defense, and retained much of last year's championship core (minus Kawhi obviously.) Lakers and Clippers have immense talent but have played flawed in the bubble.

Bumping up “no winner” until the boycott/cancellation issue is fully resolved.

Trying out different scenarios.
Strong teams of the Western Conference seem to be weaker this time around, more games mean less break and more wear and tear until conference semifinals.
Miami Heat are the first surprise. More surprises are not impossible with Oklahoma City, Utah Jazz and Dallas at least all even or in the lead so far, so "Another team" gets its weight lifted for a few days.

Interesting that the predicted likelihood of a covid outbreak that halts the playoffs is so low.  I'm not so sanguine.  No cases yet, but "Guests of players and coaches will begin to be admitted to the bubble on August 31."  Watch out once that happens.  They are in Florida after all.  And a bubble environment is only a good idea if they can keep the case numbers at zero.  If an outbreak gets started it will spread like crazy.  Following the crowd otherwise.

It makes it easier having assumptions on conference finals, playoff bracket in mind.
To me it'll be:
EC: 
Milwaukee Bucks vs Boston Celtics
WC:
Los Angeles Lakers or Houston Rockets vs Denver,Utah or Los Angeles Clippers It lowers the probability of each WC team, since there are still 5 teams competing for two spots in my mind. I don't consider Toronto Raptors strong enough to compete with Boston Celtics in the EC semifinals. Surprises in the first round would be Miami Heat (vs. Milwaukee in EC semifinals), Portland (vs. Houston in WC semifinals) and Dallas (vs. Denver/Utah), but I don't expect surprises.
Another team = Jazz, Thunder, Mavs, Trailblazers, 76ers, Heat, Magic, Nets. Heat are playing well, as are the Jazz, but this could be chalked up to the Pacers/Nuggets struggling.

Toronto team looks strong, one injury would not set them back too far.  Other teams cannot afford to have #1 - #3 players injured.
Let's start here and I'll refer to my previous notes later....

There have been 72 previous NBA champions. 48 of them have been 1 seeds, 16 were 2 seeds, 6 were 3 seeds, and 4 and 6 seeds have each won the tournament a single time. That comes out to 67, 22, 8, and 1% baselines, respectively. For the top seeds, I split the odds evenly between the two divisions since talent is not regional and should be divided evenly. For lower seeds, which haven't won in decades, I gave each about a 1% chance to take the title just to get an even spread. Upsets are always possible, but at the jump this is the simplest strategy for predicting a winner. Will update after we are further into the tournament.
Loosely following 538 numbers, interesting to note a new winner are a minimum 25% here and a 20% in the other pool.
Going to go with the 538 predictions for now. [1]  [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nba-predictions/

The four teams most likely to win are the Clippers, Lakers, Celtics, Raptors and Bucks. However, the two Western Conference teams, while they have experienced superstars, have significant shortcomings in terms of depth. This will likely limit their ability to succeed against strong defensive teams, which is why I have assigned them lower probability of success.
